name: Pythagorean trigonometric identity
explanation: The fundamental identity stating that the square of cosine plus the square of sine of an angle equals one, i.e., cos²A + sin²A = 1.

name: Sine rule for triangle side ratios
explanation: A formula relating the ratios of the lengths of sides of a triangle to the sines of their opposite angles, expressed as a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C.

name: Cosine rule for triangle side lengths
explanation: A formula to calculate the length of a side of a triangle using the lengths of the other two sides and the cosine of the included angle, given by a² = b² + c² – 2bc cos A.

name: Cosine of difference of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing cos(A–B) in terms of cosines and sines of A and B: cos(A–B) = cos A cos B + sin A sin B.

name: Cosine of sum of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing cos(A+B) in terms of cosines and sines of A and B: cos(A+B) = cos A cos B – sin A sin B.

name: Double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing cos 2A as cos²A minus sin²A: cos 2A = cos²A – sin²A.

name: Sine of sum of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing sin(A+B) as sin A cos B plus cos A sin B.

name: Sine of difference of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing sin(A–B) as sin A cos B minus cos A sin B.

name: Tangent of sum of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing tan(A+B) as (tan A + tan B) divided by (1 – tan A tan B).

name: Tangent of difference of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing tan(A–B) as (tan A – tan B) divided by (1 + tan A tan B).

name: Double angle formula for sine
explanation: An identity expressing sin 2A as 2 sin A cos A.

name: Alternative double angle formula for sine
explanation: An expression for sin 2A using other trigonometric functions (not fully specified here).

name: Alternative double angle formula for cosine
explanation: Expressions for cos 2A in terms of sine and cosine squares or other forms.

name: Double angle formula for tangent
explanation: An identity expressing tan 2A in terms of tan A (exact formula not fully specified here).

name: Power-reduction formula for cosine squared
explanation: An identity expressing cos²A as ½(1 + cos 2A), reducing the power of cosine squared.

name: Power-reduction formula for sine squared
explanation: An identity expressing sin²A as ½(1 – cos 2A), reducing the power of sine squared.

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A cos B
explanation: An identity expressing 2 cos A cos B as the sum of cos(A+B) and cos(A–B).

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A cos B
explanation: An identity expressing 2 sin A cos B as the sum of sin(A+B) and sin(A–B).

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A sin B
explanation: An identity expressing 2 sin A sin B as the difference of cos(A–B) and cos(A+B).

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A sin B
explanation: An identity expressing 2 cos A sin B as the difference of sin(A+B) and sin(A–B).

name: Sum-to-product formula for cos A + cos B
explanation: An identity expressing cos A + cos B as 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2).

name: Sum-to-product formula for cos A – cos B
explanation: An identity expressing cos A – cos B as –2 sin((A+B)/2) sin((A–B)/2).

name: Sum-to-product formula for sin A + sin B
explanation: An identity expressing sin A + sin B as 2 sin((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2).

name: Sum-to-product formula for sin A – sin B
explanation: An identity expressing sin A – sin B as 2 cos((A+B)/2) sin((A–B)/2).

name: circle drawing with given radius
explanation: Constructing a circle using a compass with a specified radius from a given center point.

name: use of straight edge in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a straight edge tool to draw precise straight lines in geometric diagrams.

name: use of compass in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a compass to draw arcs and circles accurately in geometric constructions.

name: use of ruler in geometric constructions
explanation: Applying a ruler to measure and draw straight lines with precision in geometric diagrams.

name: use of protractor in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a protractor to measure and construct angles accurately in geometric diagrams.

name: use of set square in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a set square to draw perpendicular and parallel lines and specific angles in geometric diagrams.

name: coordinating the plane
explanation: Assigning ordered pairs (x, y) to points in a plane to represent their positions numerically.

name: representing linear relationships graphically
explanation: Plotting points and drawing lines on a coordinate plane to visualize linear relationships between variables.

name: representing linear relationships in tabular form
explanation: Organizing input-output values of a linear relationship in tables to identify patterns and rates of change.

name: equivalence of slope and rate of change
explanation: Understanding that the slope of a line graphically represents the rate of change of the dependent variable with respect to the independent variable.

name: interpretation of start value in linear relationships
explanation: Identifying the initial value or y-intercept in a linear function and its significance in real-life contexts.

name: point of intersection of two linear relationships
explanation: Finding the coordinate point where two linear graphs cross, representing the solution to a system of linear equations.

name: solving real-life problems with up to two linear relationships
explanation: Using graphical, numerical, or mental strategies to find solutions involving one or two linear equations in practical contexts.

name: application of Pythagorean theorem to right-angled triangle problems
explanation: Using the relationship a² + b² = c² to find missing sides in right-angled triangles, especially in height and distance problems.

name: use of trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles
explanation: Applying sine, cosine, and tangent ratios to find unknown sides or angles in right-angled triangles in real-world problems.

name: identification of axes of symmetry in simple shapes
explanation: Locating lines that divide shapes into mirror-image halves, demonstrating symmetry properties.

name: recognition of images under translation
explanation: Understanding how points or objects move uniformly in a given direction without rotation or reflection.

name: recognition of images under central symmetry
explanation: Identifying points or objects reflected through a center point producing a rotated image by 180 degrees.

name: recognition of images under axial symmetry
explanation: Understanding reflections of points or objects across a line (axis) producing mirror images.

name: recognition of images under rotation
explanation: Identifying the position of points or objects after rotation about a fixed point through a specified angle and direction.

name: investigation of enlargements and their effect on area
explanation: Studying how scaling a figure by a scale factor k changes its size and area, considering k values less than, equal to, or greater than one.

name: centre of enlargement in dilations
explanation: The fixed point from which all points of a figure are expanded or contracted during an enlargement transformation.

name: scale factor in enlargements
explanation: The ratio k by which all distances from the centre of enlargement are multiplied to produce an enlarged or reduced image.

name: performing geometric constructions 4,5,10,13,15,16-21,22
explanation: Executing specific geometric constructions as numbered in referenced curriculum materials using standard instruments and methods.

name: use of logic and deductive reasoning terms: theorem, proof, axiom, corollary, converse, implies
explanation: Understanding and applying fundamental logical terms used in geometric reasoning and proofs.

name: use of logic and deductive reasoning terms: is equivalent to, if and only if, proof by contradiction
explanation: Applying advanced logical concepts and proof techniques to establish mathematical statements.

name: proving theorems concerning ratios in geometry
explanation: Demonstrating geometric theorems related to proportional relationships, foundational for the Pythagorean theorem proof.

name: using slope to determine parallelism of lines
explanation: Showing that two lines are parallel if and only if their slopes are equal.

name: using slope to determine perpendicularity of lines
explanation: Showing that two lines are perpendicular if the product of their slopes is -1.

name: recognition of linear equation form ax + by + c = 0
explanation: Understanding that any equation of the form ax + by + c = 0 represents a straight line in the plane.

name: calculating area of a triangle using coordinates
explanation: Determining the area of a triangle by applying coordinate geometry formulas based on vertex coordinates.

name: equation of a circle with centre (h,k) and radius r
explanation: Using the formula (x-h)² + (y-k)² = r² to represent all points equidistant r from centre (h,k).

name: equation of a circle in general form x² + y² + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0
explanation: Representing a circle with centre (-g, -f) and radius r = √(g² + f² - c) using the expanded quadratic form.

name: solving problems involving line and circle intersections
explanation: Finding points where a line and a circle intersect by solving their equations simultaneously.

name: calculating perpendicular distance from a point to a line
explanation: Determining the shortest distance between a given point and a specified line using coordinate geometry formulas.

name: calculating angle between two lines using slopes
explanation: Finding the angle formed by two intersecting lines from their slopes using the tangent formula for angle between lines.

name: internal division of a line segment in ratio m:n
explanation: Finding coordinates of a point dividing a line segment internally into parts proportional to m and n.

name: definition of sine and cosine for all angle values
explanation: Extending the sine and cosine functions to all real angle measures, including negative and angles greater than 360° or 2π radians.

name: definition of tangent function
explanation: Defining tangent as the ratio of sine to cosine for any angle where cosine is not zero.

name: calculating area of a sector of a circle
explanation: Using the formula (1/2) r² θ (in radians) to find the area of a sector defined by central angle θ and radius r.

name: calculating length of an arc of a circle
explanation: Finding the length of an arc using the formula r θ where θ is the central angle in radians and r is the radius.

name: working with trigonometric ratios in surd form
explanation: Expressing sine, cosine, and tangent values using irrational numbers in simplest radical form.

name: solving 3D problems using trigonometry
explanation: Applying trigonometric ratios and formulas to find lengths and angles in three-dimensional contexts.

name: graphing sine, cosine, and tangent functions
explanation: Plotting the periodic graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent functions over specified domains.

name: graphing trigonometric functions of the form f(θ) = a + b sin(cθ)
explanation: Plotting sine functions with vertical shifts, amplitude changes, and frequency adjustments based on parameters a, b, and c.

name: graphing trigonometric functions of the form g(θ) = a + b cos(cθ)
explanation: Plotting cosine functions with vertical shifts, amplitude changes, and frequency adjustments based on parameters a, b, and c.

name: solving trigonometric equations sin nθ = 0
explanation: Finding all angle solutions θ that satisfy the equation where sine of n times θ equals zero.

name: solving trigonometric equations cos nθ = 1/2
explanation: Finding all angle solutions θ where cosine of n times θ equals one half.

name: use of radian measure of angles
explanation: Measuring angles based on the radius of a circle, where one radian is the angle subtended by an arc equal in length to the radius.

name: derivation of fundamental trigonometric formulae
explanation: Proving key trigonometric identities and formulas used to simplify and solve trigonometric problems.

name: application of trigonometric formulae 1-24
explanation: Using a comprehensive set of trigonometric identities and formulas to solve various problems in trigonometry.

name: solving problems involving slopes of lines
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: solving problems involving slopes of lines

name: solving problems involving the area of a sector of a circle and the length of an arc
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: solving problems involving the area of a sector of a circle and the length of an arc

name: natural numbers (N)
explanation: The set of positive integers starting from 1, used for counting and ordering.

name: integers (Z)
explanation: The set of whole numbers including positive, negative numbers and zero.

name: rational numbers (Q)
explanation: Numbers that can be expressed as a fraction of two integers, including fractions and decimals with finite or repeating decimal representations.

name: decimal representation of rational numbers
explanation: Representation of rational numbers as decimals that either terminate or repeat periodically.

name: percentage as representation of rational numbers
explanation: Expressing rational numbers as parts per hundred to compare proportions.

name: addition of natural numbers using models
explanation: Performing addition within natural numbers using models like decomposition, skip counting, and arrays.

name: subtraction of natural numbers using models
explanation: Performing subtraction within natural numbers using models such as decomposition and skip counting.

name: multiplication of natural numbers using arrays and grouping
explanation: Understanding multiplication as repeated addition using arrays and grouping equal sets.

name: division of natural numbers using grouping and sharing
explanation: Understanding division as partitioning or grouping into equal parts within natural numbers.

name: inverse operations within natural numbers
explanation: Understanding addition and subtraction, multiplication and division as inverse operations within natural numbers.

name: properties of arithmetic: commutative law
explanation: The property that the order of addition or multiplication does not affect the result (e.g., a + b = b + a).

name: properties of arithmetic: associative law
explanation: The property that the grouping of numbers in addition or multiplication does not affect the result (e.g., (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)).

name: properties of arithmetic: distributive law
explanation: The property that multiplication distributes over addition or subtraction (e.g., a(b + c) = ab + ac).

name: order of operations including brackets
explanation: Rules that define the sequence in which arithmetic operations are performed, prioritizing brackets, exponents, multiplication/division, and addition/subtraction.

name: addition with negative integers
explanation: Performing addition involving negative numbers by applying arithmetic properties and contextual understanding.

name: subtraction with negative integers
explanation: Performing subtraction involving negative numbers using arithmetic properties and real-life contexts.

name: multiplication with negative integers
explanation: Performing multiplication involving negative numbers by applying arithmetic properties.

name: division with negative integers
explanation: Performing division involving negative numbers using arithmetic properties.

name: number line representation of natural numbers
explanation: Using a number line to represent and order natural numbers visually.

name: number line representation of integers
explanation: Using a number line to represent and order integers including negative numbers and zero.

name: number line representation of rational numbers
explanation: Using a number line to represent and order rational numbers including fractions and decimals.

name: irrational numbers recognition
explanation: Identifying numbers that cannot be expressed as fractions of integers and have non-repeating, non-terminating decimal expansions.

name: real numbers (R) and their subsets
explanation: The set of all rational and irrational numbers combined, representing points on the continuous number line.

name: complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Numbers expressed as a + ib where a and b are real numbers and i is the imaginary unit with i² = -1.

name: Argand diagram representation of complex numbers
explanation: Graphical representation of complex numbers as points or vectors in the plane with real and imaginary axes.

name: modulus of a complex number
explanation: The distance of a complex number from the origin on the Argand diagram, calculated as the square root of the sum of squares of real and imaginary parts.

name: complex conjugate
explanation: The complex number obtained by changing the sign of the imaginary part of a complex number a + ib to a - ib.

name: decimal as special equivalent fraction
explanation: Expressing decimals as fractions with denominators that are powers of ten, strengthening understanding of place value.

name: factors of natural numbers
explanation: Numbers that divide a given natural number exactly without remainder.

name: multiples of natural numbers
explanation: Numbers obtained by multiplying a given natural number by an integer.

name: prime numbers in natural numbers
explanation: Natural numbers greater than 1 that have no positive divisors other than 1 and themselves.

name: prime factorization
explanation: Expressing a natural number as a product of its prime factors.

name: scientific notation for positive rational numbers
explanation: Expressing numbers in the form a × 10^n where 1 ≤ a < 10 and n is an integer.

name: geometric construction of square roots
explanation: Using geometric methods to construct lengths representing √2 and √3.

name: proof of irrationality of √2
explanation: Mathematical proof demonstrating that √2 cannot be expressed as a ratio of integers.

name: calculation of conjugates of sums and products of complex numbers
explanation: Finding the conjugate of sums and products of complex numbers using algebraic properties.

name: verification of formulae from number patterns
explanation: Proving algebraic formulae derived from observed numerical sequences or patterns.

name: investigation of geometric sequences
explanation: Studying sequences where each term is found by multiplying the previous term by a constant ratio.

name: investigation of geometric series
explanation: Studying the sum of terms in a geometric sequence.

name: mathematical induction for sum of first n natural numbers
explanation: Proof technique to establish that the sum of the first n natural numbers equals n(n+1)/2.

name: mathematical induction for sum of finite geometric series
explanation: Using induction to prove the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series.

name: mathematical induction for inequalities
explanation: Using induction to prove inequalities such as n! > 2^n for n ≥ 4.

name: factorisation results via induction
explanation: Using induction to prove divisibility and factorisation properties, e.g., 3 divides 4^n - 1.

name: limits of sequences
explanation: Determining the value that terms of a sequence approach as the index goes to infinity.

name: limits of geometric sequences
explanation: Finding the limit of sequences where each term is multiplied by a constant ratio r as n approaches infinity.

name: sum to infinity of geometric series
explanation: Calculating the sum of an infinite geometric series by considering the limit of partial sums.

name: recurring decimals as infinite geometric series
explanation: Representing repeating decimals as sums of infinite geometric series.

name: equality as a relationship of expressions
explanation: Understanding equality as the condition where two mathematical expressions represent the same value.

name: percentage calculation
explanation: Computing values expressed as parts per hundred to compare proportions and solve related problems.

name: equivalence of fractions, decimals, and percentages
explanation: Understanding and using the relationships between fractions, decimals, and percentages to compare proportions.

name: ratio and proportion relationships
explanation: Understanding the relationship between two quantities and how they scale relative to each other.

name: checking results by order of magnitude
explanation: Verifying the plausibility of a result by comparing its size to expected scales and working backwards.

name: rounding off results
explanation: Approximating numerical answers to a specified degree of accuracy.

name: making and justifying estimates and approximations
explanation: Developing reasonable numerical estimates and explaining their appropriateness.

name: expressing numbers in scientific notation
explanation: Writing non-zero positive rational numbers in the form a × 10^n with 1 ≤ a < 10 and integer n.

name: indices as squares and cubes
explanation: Representing numbers raised to the power of 2 (squares) and 3 (cubes).

name: indices as square roots and reciprocals
explanation: Representing numbers raised to fractional powers such as 1/2 (square root) and negative powers (reciprocals).

name: recognition and continuation of numerical sequences
explanation: Identifying patterns in sequences and using them to predict subsequent terms.

name: generalisation of sequences in algebraic form
explanation: Expressing patterns and relationships in sequences using algebraic expressions.

name: recognition of arithmetic sequences
explanation: Identifying sequences where the difference between consecutive terms is constant.

name: recognition of geometric sequences
explanation: Identifying sequences where each term is found by multiplying the previous term by a constant ratio.

name: sum to n terms of arithmetic series
explanation: Calculating the sum of the first n terms of an arithmetic sequence.

name: rules of indices: product rule
explanation: For the same base, multiply powers by adding exponents: a^p × a^q = a^(p+q).

name: rules of indices: quotient rule
explanation: For the same base, divide powers by subtracting exponents: a^p ÷ a^q = a^(p−q).

name: rules of indices: zero exponent rule
explanation: Any non-zero base raised to the zero power equals 1: a^0 = 1.

name: rules of indices: power of a power
explanation: Raising a power to another power multiplies the exponents: (a^p)^q = a^(pq).

name: rules of indices: negative exponent rule
explanation: A negative exponent indicates the reciprocal: a^(−p) = 1/a^p.

name: rules of indices: power of a product
explanation: The power of a product equals the product of the powers: (ab)^p = a^p b^p.

name: rules of indices: power of a quotient
explanation: The power of a quotient equals the quotient of the powers: (a/b)^p = a^p / b^p.

name: logarithm product rule
explanation: The logarithm of a product equals the sum of the logarithms: log_a(xy) = log_a x + log_a y.

name: logarithm quotient rule
explanation: The logarithm of a quotient equals the difference of the logarithms: log_a(x/y) = log_a x − log_a y.

name: logarithm power rule
explanation: The logarithm of a power equals the exponent times the logarithm: log_a(x^q) = q log_a x.

name: logarithm of base and one
explanation: log_a a = 1 and log_a 1 = 0 for any valid base a.

name: change of base formula for logarithms
explanation: Expressing logarithm in one base in terms of another: log_a x = log_b x / log_b a.

name: solving everyday arithmetic problems
explanation: Applying arithmetic operations to solve real-life problems such as tariffs, currency exchange, shopping, VAT, and timetables.

name: value for money calculations
explanation: Calculating and comparing costs and benefits to make financial judgments.

name: ratio and proportion applications
explanation: Using ratios and proportions to solve problems involving relative quantities.

name: profit and loss calculations
explanation: Computing profit or loss amounts and percentages based on cost price and selling price.

name: discount and percentage discount calculations
explanation: Calculating reductions in price and their percentage equivalents.

name: compound interest calculations (up to 3 years)
explanation: Calculating interest earned on principal and accumulated interest over up to three years.

name: income tax and net pay calculations
explanation: Computing deductions such as income tax and other specified amounts to find net pay.

name: average speed, distance, and time calculations
explanation: Solving problems relating speed, distance traveled, and time taken using the formula distance = speed × time.

name: 2D shapes and 3D solids recognition
explanation: Identifying and working with two-dimensional shapes and three-dimensional solids including their nets.

name: nets of solids
explanation: Two-dimensional layouts that can be folded to form three-dimensional solids.

name: perimeter calculation of plane figures
explanation: Finding the total length around 2D shapes such as discs, triangles, rectangles, and squares.

name: area calculation of plane figures
explanation: Computing the surface area within the boundaries of 2D shapes including combinations of regular and irregular shapes.

name: volume calculation of rectangular solids
explanation: Finding the amount of space occupied by rectangular prisms using length × width × height.

name: volume calculation of cylinders
explanation: Calculating the space inside a cylinder using the formula π × radius² × height.

name: surface area calculation of solids
explanation: Finding the total area of all the faces or curved surfaces of 3D solids such as cylinders, spheres, and rectangular solids.

name: scaled diagram drawing and interpretation
explanation: Creating and understanding diagrams drawn to scale to represent real objects or situations.

name: accumulated error by addition and subtraction
explanation: Understanding how errors combine when adding or subtracting measurements or calculations.

name: percentage error and tolerance calculation
explanation: Calculating the relative error as a percentage and understanding acceptable error margins (tolerances).

name: average rate of change calculation
explanation: Computing the average change of a quantity with respect to time or another variable.

name: depreciation using reducing balance method
explanation: Calculating the decrease in value of an asset by applying a fixed percentage reduction each period.

name: costing including materials, labour, and wastage
explanation: Calculating total cost by considering materials, labour charges, and wastage amounts.

name: metric and imperial unit conversions
explanation: Converting measurements between metric units and everyday imperial units using conversion factors.

name: nets of prisms, cylinders, and cones
explanation: Two-dimensional layouts that fold to form prisms, cylinders, and cones.

name: perimeter and area of sectors of discs
explanation: Calculating the length of the arc and area of a sector (a 'slice') of a circle.

name: surface area and volume of cones
explanation: Calculating the curved surface area, total surface area, and volume of cones.

name: surface area and volume of triangular-based prisms
explanation: Calculating surface area and volume of prisms with triangular bases, including right angle, isosceles, and equilateral triangles.

name: surface area and volume of spheres and hemispheres
explanation: Calculating total surface area and volume of spheres and hemispheres.

name: use of trapezoidal rule to approximate area
explanation: Estimating the area under a curve by dividing it into trapezoids and summing their areas.

name: present value in loan repayments and investments
explanation: Calculating the current worth of a future sum of money or stream of cash flows given a specified rate of return.

name: function as a unique input-output assignment
explanation: Understanding that a function assigns exactly one output value for each input value.

name: graphing linear functions with rational coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = ax + b where a and b are rational numbers and x is a real number.

name: forming composite functions
explanation: Creating a new function by applying one function to the result of another function, denoted as (f∘g)(x) = f(g(x)).

name: graphing quadratic functions with integer coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = ax² + bx + c where a, b, c are integers and x is a real number.

name: graphing cubic functions with integer coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = ax³ + bx² + cx + d where a, b, c, d are integers and x is a real number.

name: graphing exponential functions with natural base coefficient
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = ab^x where a is a natural number and b, x are real numbers.

name: interpreting equations as function comparisons
explanation: Understanding equations of the form f(x) = g(x) as comparing outputs of two functions to find points of equality.

name: graphical solution of equations f(x) = 0
explanation: Using graphs to find approximate values of x where the function f(x) crosses the x-axis (roots).

name: graphical solution of equations f(x) = k
explanation: Using graphs to find approximate values of x where the function f(x) equals a constant k.

name: graphical solution of equations f(x) = g(x)
explanation: Using graphs to find approximate values of x where two functions have equal outputs.

name: concept of limit of a function
explanation: Investigating the value that a function approaches as the input approaches a particular point.

name: recognising surjective functions
explanation: Identifying functions where every possible output is mapped to by at least one input (onto functions).

name: recognising injective functions
explanation: Identifying functions where each output corresponds to at most one input (one-to-one functions).

name: recognising bijective functions
explanation: Identifying functions that are both injective and surjective, establishing a one-to-one correspondence between inputs and outputs.

name: finding inverse of a bijective function
explanation: Determining the function that reverses the mapping of a bijective function, swapping inputs and outputs.

name: sketching inverse function graphs from original function graphs
explanation: Drawing the graph of the inverse function by reflecting the original function's graph across the line y = x.

name: expressing quadratic functions in complete square form
explanation: Rewriting quadratic functions as f(x) = a(x-h)² + k to identify vertex and simplify analysis.

name: using complete square form to find roots and turning points
explanation: Employing the vertex form of a quadratic to determine the function's zeros and vertex coordinates.

name: graphing quadratic functions with rational coefficients
explanation: Plotting quadratic functions where coefficients a, b, c are rational numbers and x is real.

name: graphing exponential functions with real coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = ab^x where a and b are real numbers with a > 0.

name: graphing logarithmic functions
explanation: Plotting functions that are the inverse of exponential functions, typically of the form f(x) = log_b(x).

name: graphing trigonometric functions
explanation: Plotting periodic functions such as sine, cosine, and tangent over real numbers.

name: informal exploration of limits and continuity
explanation: Investigating how functions behave near points and whether they have breaks or jumps without formal epsilon-delta proofs.

name: finding first derivatives of linear, quadratic, and cubic functions by rule
explanation: Calculating the rate of change of polynomial functions of degree one to three using differentiation rules.

name: finding second derivatives of linear, quadratic, and cubic functions by rule
explanation: Calculating the derivative of the first derivative to analyze concavity and acceleration of polynomial functions.

name: associating derivatives with slopes and tangent lines
explanation: Understanding that the derivative at a point gives the slope of the tangent line to the function's graph at that point.

name: applying differentiation to rates of change
explanation: Using derivatives to calculate how quantities change with respect to one another in various contexts.

name: applying differentiation to find maxima and minima
explanation: Using derivatives to locate points where functions reach local maximum or minimum values.

name: applying differentiation to curve sketching
explanation: Using first and second derivatives to analyze and sketch the shape and features of graphs.

name: differentiating linear and quadratic functions from first principles
explanation: Calculating derivatives using the limit definition rather than rules for linear and quadratic functions.

name: differentiating polynomial functions
explanation: Applying rules to find derivatives of polynomial functions of any degree.

name: differentiating exponential functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of functions where the variable is in the exponent.

name: differentiating trigonometric functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of sine, cosine, and other trigonometric functions.

name: differentiating functions with rational powers
explanation: Finding derivatives of functions where variables are raised to fractional exponents.

name: differentiating inverse functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of functions that are inverses of other functions using appropriate rules.

name: differentiating logarithmic functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of logarithmic functions such as natural log and log base b.

name: differentiating sums, differences, products, quotients, and compositions of functions
explanation: Applying differentiation rules including sum, difference, product, quotient, and chain rules to combinations of functions.

name: using differentiation to find slope of tangent to a circle
explanation: Applying derivative concepts to determine the slope of the tangent line at a point on a circle.

name: recognising integration as reverse process of differentiation
explanation: Understanding that integration undoes differentiation, recovering the original function from its derivative.

name: using integration to find average value of a function over an interval
explanation: Calculating the mean value of a function on a given interval using definite integrals.

name: integrating sums, differences, and constant multiples of power functions
explanation: Applying integration rules to functions of the form x^a where a is rational, including linear multiples.

name: integrating exponential functions of the form a^x
explanation: Finding integrals of exponential functions with positive real bases.

name: integrating sine functions with real coefficients
explanation: Calculating integrals of functions of the form sin(ax) where a is a real number.

name: integrating cosine functions with real coefficients
explanation: Calculating integrals of functions of the form cos(ax) where a is a real number.

name: determining areas of plane regions bounded by polynomial curves
explanation: Using definite integrals to find the area enclosed between polynomial function graphs and the x-axis or other curves.

name: determining areas of plane regions bounded by exponential curves
explanation: Using definite integrals to find the area enclosed between exponential function graphs and the x-axis or other curves.

name: determining areas of plane regions bounded by polynomial and exponential curves
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: determining areas of plane regions bounded by polynomial and exponential curves

name: using tables to represent repeating-pattern situations
explanation: Constructing tables that map inputs to outputs to represent and analyze repeating numerical or visual patterns.

name: generalising and explaining numerical patterns in words and numbers
explanation: Describing the rule or relationship governing a pattern using verbal and numerical expressions.

name: writing arithmetic expressions for particular terms in a sequence
explanation: Formulating arithmetic expressions that represent the nth term or specific terms in a numerical sequence.

name: representing linear patterns with tables, diagrams, and graphs
explanation: Using tables, visual diagrams, and coordinate graphs to model and analyze linear relationships and patterns.

name: developing and using generalising strategies for patterns
explanation: Creating and applying methods to identify and extend patterns or relationships, including considering others' approaches.

name: presenting and interpreting solutions with justification
explanation: Communicating problem solutions clearly with explanations and reasoning to support conclusions.

name: finding underlying formulae for linear relationships from data
explanation: Deriving algebraic formulae that describe linear relationships based on observed data or patterns.

name: identifying features of linear relationships in multiple representations
explanation: Recognizing characteristics such as rate of change and intercepts in tables, graphs, models, and verbal or algebraic formulae.

name: discussing rate of change and y-intercept in context
explanation: Explaining how the slope (rate of change) and y-intercept relate to real-world situations and appear in different representations.

name: determining common values of two linear relationships
explanation: Finding points where two linear functions have the same output value, often by solving equations or comparing graphs.

name: recognising and solving direct proportion problems
explanation: Identifying situations where two quantities vary directly and using proportional reasoning to solve related problems.

name: exploring graphs of motion quantitatively
explanation: Analyzing graphs that represent motion to understand changes in position, speed, or acceleration over time.

name: connecting graph shape to phenomena stories
explanation: Relating the visual form of a graph to the real-world event or process it represents, interpreting both quantity and change.

name: evaluating algebraic expressions given variable values
explanation: Substituting numerical values into algebraic expressions and calculating the resulting value.

name: expanding and regrouping algebraic expressions
explanation: Applying distributive property and combining like terms to rewrite expressions in expanded or simplified form.

name: factorising quadratic expressions of order 2
explanation: Rewriting second-degree polynomial expressions as products of binomials or simpler factors.

name: adding and subtracting linear and quadratic expressions with integer coefficients
explanation: Performing addition and subtraction on expressions of the form (ax+by+c) and (ax²+bx+c) where coefficients are integers.

name: simplifying expressions using associative and distributive properties
explanation: Applying associative and distributive laws to simplify expressions involving sums and products of terms with integer coefficients.

name: rearranging formulae
explanation: Manipulating algebraic equations to isolate a specified variable on one side.

name: performing arithmetic operations on polynomials and rational algebraic expressions
explanation: Adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing polynomial and rational expressions, including handling brackets and surds.

name: applying the binomial theorem
explanation: Using the binomial theorem to expand expressions of the form (a + b)^n for positive integer n.

name: solving linear equations of the form f(x) = g(x) with rational coefficients
explanation: Finding solutions to linear equations where f(x) and g(x) are linear expressions with rational number coefficients.

name: selecting graphic, numeric, and mental strategies for equation solving
explanation: Using graphs, tables of values, and mental arithmetic to find solutions to equations.

name: solving simultaneous linear equations with two unknowns
explanation: Finding values of variables that satisfy two linear equations simultaneously.

name: solving systems involving one linear and one quadratic equation with two unknowns
explanation: Finding solutions to systems where one equation is linear and the other is quadratic, with constraints on coefficients for simplification.

name: forming quadratic equations given whole number roots
explanation: Constructing quadratic equations when the roots (solutions) are known integers.

name: using the Factor Theorem for polynomials
explanation: Applying the Factor Theorem to determine if a linear binomial is a factor of a polynomial and to find roots.

name: solving cubic equations with at least one integer root
explanation: Finding solutions to third-degree polynomial equations that have at least one root which is an integer.

name: solving simultaneous linear equations with three unknowns
explanation: Finding values of three variables that satisfy three linear equations simultaneously.

name: solving linear inequalities of the form g(x) ≤ k or g(x) ≥ k with rational coefficients
explanation: Finding solution sets for linear inequalities where g(x) is linear and coefficients and constants are rational numbers.

name: solving linear inequalities of the form g(x) < k or g(x) > k with rational coefficients
explanation: Finding solution sets for strict linear inequalities with rational coefficients.

name: solving quadratic inequalities of the form g(x) ≤ k or g(x) ≥ k
explanation: Determining solution sets for inequalities where g(x) is a quadratic expression and coefficients are rational.

name: solving absolute value inequalities of the form |x – a| < b or |x – a| > b
explanation: Finding solution sets for inequalities involving the absolute value of linear expressions.

name: using the Conjugate Root Theorem to find polynomial roots
explanation: Applying the theorem that complex roots of polynomials with real coefficients occur in conjugate pairs to find roots.

name: working with complex numbers in rectangular and polar form
explanation: Representing and manipulating complex numbers using Cartesian coordinates (a + bi) and polar coordinates (r(cos θ + i sin θ)).

name: solving quadratic and other equations using complex numbers
explanation: Finding solutions to polynomial equations that include complex roots, using complex number arithmetic.

name: using De Moivre’s Theorem for powers of complex numbers
explanation: Applying De Moivre’s Theorem to raise complex numbers in polar form to integer powers.

name: proving De Moivre’s Theorem by mathematical induction
explanation: Using induction to establish the validity of De Moivre’s Theorem for all natural numbers n.

name: applying nth roots of unity and trigonometric identities
explanation: Using complex number theory to find nth roots of unity and proving identities such as Cos 3θ = 4 Cos³ θ – 3 Cos θ.
